18774.title: What should I know before travelling?

nodes.text: How do I manage a situation where I am asked for a facilitation payment?
What is a facilitation payment?
What do I do if I feel threatened in any way or coerced into paying?
If you feel that your safety or liberty is threatened and you are being coerced into paying, then you should pay.
You must record the payment and the circumstances and report them as soon as possible to your line manager and the legal or compliance department.
Record the payment clearly and when claiming the cost back from the company, make sure it is clearly identified and accounted for

Giving an unearned reward to influence someone’s behaviour or approving an irregular payment to facilitate business processes is a form of bribery.  It is illegal.  This especially includes being asked for a fee by a supplier to arrange signatures. This is and could be interpreted by others as a bribe.
We do not offer, give or receive bribes or make improper payments, or participate in any kind of corrupt activity, either directly or through any third party.

Engaging in any form of bribery or corruption, even an allegation, can result in criminal proscecution and can seriously damage our reputation and our business relationships and is never acceptable.  We would rather miss out on business than take this risk.
Do not pay.  Take action immediately. Report the situation to your line manager and the legal department.
Record any details of the request (time, date, by whom and how it was asked for).

There is a risk that you are being asked to make an unauthorised payment.  Paying a small sum of money to an official as a fine can be a facilitation payment in disguise. No matter how small the amount, facilitation payments are illegal in most countries in which we operate and UK law forbids them anywhere in the world.  Even if not instigated by you, paying facilitation payments can seriously damage our reputation.

You should strongly resist any demand for this kind of payment. Remain calm and be prepared to wait.  Showing impatience can increase pressure to pay.  Say no and use the following to help you challenge the fee.
Remain courteous, respectful and if possible friendly.
Ask to speak to the supervisor/manager of the person making the demand to discuss why you cant pay.
State that you would need an official receipt if you were to pay the fine and guage the response.
Make it clear that your company does not allow you to make irregular, non-standard or unofficial payments of any kind.
Ask for name and official title of person asking and any identity number.
Mention that you will contact the embassy / consulate to discuss / report the issue.
Explain that you must call your company first to report the issue and to get permission to pay the fee.
Take notes or make mental note of the conversations and the time and place for a later report.
Do you feel threatened in any way or are you being coerced into paying?
Yes
No

Cash or equivalents are much harder to trace and account for. It is safer to decline than take the risk

Whilst you may believe that the cash or equivalent is offered with no ulterior motive, gifts of this nature are much more likely to be misinterpreted by others who could perceive the acceptance of the gift as making you or your decisions biased, conflicted or obligated.  It is safer to decline than take the risk.
